awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multidisciplinary Analysis of Antarctic Blue Ice Moraine Formation and their Potential as Climate Archives over Multiple Glacial Cycles
awd_abstract_narration:
Licht/1443433

Sediments deposited by the Antarctic ice sheet are an archive of its history with time and help geologists to determine how the remote interior of the ice sheet has changed over the past several hundred thousand years.  This project will focus on the formation and dynamics of moraines (accumulations of dirt and rocks that are incorporated in the glacier surface or have been pushed along by the glacier as it moves) near the blue ice area of Mt. Achernar in the central Transantarctic Mountains in Antarctica.. The study will improve basic understanding of the formation of these moraines. Fieldwork at the site will focus on imaging the internal structure of the moraine to determine the processes by which it, and others like it, form over time.  Additional analyses will include measurements of ice flow and collection of rock samples to determine the timing of debris deposition and the changes in the sources of sediments from deep within the Antarctic continent. The project will provide both graduate and undergraduate students training in paleoclimate studies, geology, and numerical modeling approaches. The broader impacts of the proposed work include hands on training in the Earth Sciences for graduate and undergraduate students, collaboration with colleagues in New Zealand and Sweden to provide an international research experience for students from the US, and three educational modules to be delivered by student researchers regarding Antarctica's role in global environments. The research is societally relevant and multidisciplinary and the topics are ideal for sharing with the public. All research findings will be made publicly available to others via timely publication in high-impact, peer-reviewed journals and all data will be submitted to the National Snow and Ice Data Center, and excess samples will be provided to the U.S. Polar Rock Repository.

Direct observations of ice sheet history from the margins of Antarctica's polar plateau are essential for testing numerical ice sheet models, and the laterally extensive, blue-ice moraines of the Mt. Achernar Moraine complex in the central Transantarctic Mountains contain a unique and nearly untapped direct, quasi-continuous record of ice sheet change over multiple glacial cycles.  The project objectives include improved understanding of processes and rates of blue ice moraine formation, as well as identifying the topographic, glaciological, and climatic controls on their evolution. Data to be collected with fieldwork in Antarctica include: imaging of internal ice structure with ground-penetrating radar, measurement of ice flow velocity and direction with a global positioning system (GPS) array, analysis of debris concentration and composition in glacier ice, state-of-the-art cosmogenic multi-nuclide analyses to determine exposure ages of moraine debris, mapping of trimlines and provenance analysis.  Numerical model simulations, constrained by field data, will be used to evaluate the factors influencing changes in glacier flow that potentially impact the accumulation of the moraine debris.  All together, the new data and modeling efforts will improve conceptual models of blue ice moraine formation, and thereby make them a more valuable proxy for developing a better understanding of the history of the ice sheet.

por.por_cntn:
Our aim is to study recent and past behavior of the central part of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet. We focused our work at the head of Law Glacier, which helps drain the East Antarctic Ice Sheet through the Transantarctic Mountains. At Mt. Achernar, sediments left behind by ice provide an excellent setting for studying past changes of the center of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet, which stores the largest amount of freshwater volume on Earth. The sediments contain a direct and quasi-continuous record of how the ice sheet has changed over time. At this location, the ice sheet flows off the high plateau and gets funneled through the Transantartic Mountains, on the way to the sea. Part of our aim is to provide observations of the former ice sheet during past warm and cold periods, to help evaluate the sensitivity of this sector to past (natural) climate variability.

There were several important objectives. First, to carry out a highly successful field campaign in a remote area in the central Transantarctic Mountains, at the head of the Law Glacier, from our own small camp. Second, to obtain unique datasets that directly bear on the timing of the former glacier surface as it has flowed off the plateau and into the Transantarctic Mountains. A general problem is that it is very difficult to obtain information on past Antarctic Ice Sheet surfaces, or any past ice sheet surface for that matter, as evidence of former limits is typically not preserved. The project's focus, the Mt. Achernar area, is a nunatack that pokes through the ice sheet, which gets around this problem because evidence of former ice surfaces is still preserved. Additional objectives include integrating our findings with those obtained in the project by other colleagues, for example, on the study of imaging the ice below the surface, glacier velocity and dynamics, and origins of the sediments we analyzed.

The intellectual merit of the project stems from the fact that it is critical to improve our knowledge of how the center of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet has changed in the past. Has the Ice Sheet been particularly sensitive and retreated during prior warm periods, or has the center even grown slightly because of more snow? We obtained observations directly on former ice surface elevations of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet over the last few hundred thousand years.

To summarize the outcomes, our findings provide new knowledge of how the East Antarctic Ice Sheet has changed in the past, including during both cold and warm periods. We find the center of the ice sheet experienced little change over the last few hundred thousand years. These changes, on the order of tens of meters for the center of the ice sheet, are relatively small compared to other sectors. This includes around 130,000 to 100,000 years ago, when sectors of West Antarctica may have retreated in a warm period known as the last interglacial; even if such changes occurred elsewhere, the core of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet essentially remained unchanged. The oldest sediment observed was close to 500,000-400,000 years old, suggesting there may have been significant thinning around that time, or slightly before. The last relatively minor lowering of the Law Glacier surface started after or around 10,000 years ago, and we infer continues towards the present. We also focused on how to improve and interpret approaches that are used to reconstruct former glacier surfaces over time and date sediment left behind by the ice sheet.

In terms of broader impacts, understanding the history of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet as it flows into the Transantarctic Mountains is of interest to other scientists and society for several reasons. The most important is that this sector of the ice sheet contains the largest store of freshwater on Earth, and has potential to influence dramatically sea level. Hence, knowledge of its sensitivity to warm periods in the past provides critical insights. Our findings are relevant, overall, for all disciplines interested in the history of the Antarctic Ice Sheet-climate system and the geologic archives recorded in the Transantarctic Mountains. The work also has relevance for researchers who model present and future ice sheet scenarios; these researchers require observations of past configurations of Antarctic ice to test the robustness of their models. Last, we pushed the envelope in terms of our analyses over recent time scales, and when sediment had recently emerged from Law Glacier.

In terms of other broader impacts, the project has provided several researchers at different career stages, including graduate students and postdocs, with new research experience and expertise in working in various aspects of Antarctic science. These experiences include interactions with the media and presentations to non-scientific audiences including talking to a school audience from Antarctica.
